awd_titl_txt: Institute for Meta-Synthesis: A Practicum through the Lens of STEM Equity and Inclusion Literature
awd_abstract_narration:
TERC, Inc. will implement an Institute in Research Methods that will build capacity in qualitative meta-synthesis methods, with an emphasis on STEM equity and inclusion literature. The institute responds to the need for greater emphasis on meta-synthesis methods in STEM education research, the lack of preparation among researchers to conduct these studies, and the need to diversify the pool of STEM education researchers broadly.  Institute participants are expected to build capacity in meta-synthesis skills, including location of relevant literature, identification of high-quality research, synthesis memo creation, and systematic thematic analysis. Through the lens of equity and inclusion literature, participants will learn how to identify and frame emergent themes and theorize  findings.  Targeted participants will include graduate students, post-doctoral scholars, and early career investigators in STEM education research, particularly those from underrepresented groups.  The project team will pursue three primary objectives: (1) Develop a flexible set of materials and experiences that provide participants with on-ramps for building skills and competencies in qualitative meta-synthesis. (2) Implement workshops, webinars, seminars, intensive coaching, and other hands-on activities that allow participants to apply meta-synthesis methods. (3) Create and disseminate on-demand modules, user guides, and other supporting materials for individual use and future course offerings at participants’ institutions. In addition to broadening the representation of underrepresented groups in the STEM education research community, the institute can fill the knowledge gaps on equity and inclusion topics in STEM education research literature.

The institute will capitalize on equity and inclusion STEM literature for systematic meta-synthesis training. This approach employs systematic search and selection processes and thematic analysis of findings. The team will use established pre-search methods and a hybrid approach for coding that are substantiated in the literature and grounded in theory to frame the modules. The pedagogical approach involves creating an environment of reciprocity between learner and teacher and among learners. The delivery formats include six intensive course modules, an introductory level workshop, a short seminar, a synchronous webinar, and on-demand modules.  The modular nature of the meta-synthesis curriculum allows for flexibility to address the learning needs of particular communities, and the individualized coaching and technical assistance provided by the project team will deepen participants’ understanding of synthesis techniques in a supportive  structure. The Institute also will offer coaching and technical support for a subset of participants who complete the six modules and implement strong participant recruitment efforts among minority-serving institutions. The ultimate goal is that participants will be able to design and execute successful meta-synthesis projects that can enrich the STEM education research knowledge base. 

The project is supported by the ECR: Building Capacity in STEM Education Research competition of the EHR Core Research Program (ECR). ECR funds fundamental STEM education research projects that focus on STEM learning/learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM professional workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2020, TERC was awarded an NSF Building Capacity in STEM Education Research (BCSER) Institute in Research Methods grant for a project entitled, Institute for Meta-Synthesis: A Practicum through the Lens of STEM Equity and Inclusion Literature (IMS). IMS was a four-year project that built the capacity of primarily early career scholars in qualitative literature meta-synthesis methods and synthesis proposal development skills, with a special focus on STEM equity and inclusion literature.

Intellectual Merit: Enhancing Research Capacity

Between 2020 and 2024, the IMS team taught qualitative meta-synthesis methods to over 2,400 faculty, early career researchers, and graduate students across 32 seminars and workshops. Participants became equipped with skills for executing successful meta-synthesis projects, including developing effective synthesis questions; searching for literature; developing and applying selection criteria; and coding and conducting thematic analysis. They also learned about writing meta-synthesis manuscripts and constructing competitive synthesis grant proposals. IMS events were free, taught at the introductory level, and averaged 3.5 hours. The events, which ranged between one and 30 hours, were customized according to the needs of participants and in collaboration with sponsoring organizations or partnering institutions. Participant feedback was overall positive and attested to how IMS filled a gap in the field. For example, in Year 1, following three IMS events (n = 636), most respondents reported that, while they had no prior experience with meta-synthesis (80.6%), they now had increased knowledge (85.3%) about and increased confidence (89.0%) in performing meta-synthesis activities. Similarly, following a national workshop in Year 3, most respondents (n = 68) rated the workshop as being "very much" suited to their own research training needs (65.0%) and rated the overall course as "excellent" (77.5%).

In addition to its introductory offerings, IMS piloted an advanced, four-day workshop. With a cohort of 15 participants, the workshop was designed with personalized activities and coaching to help researchers significantly progress in their own projects. The pilot resulted in a strong set of outcomes, including active post-workshop cohort gatherings; multiple presentations and publications; grant proposals focused on meta-synthesis; and ongoing research on the inclusion of artificial intelligence in memo generation and analysis. Furthermore, several participants expressed interest in teaching qualitative meta-synthesis methods in the future. The advanced workshop served as a model for the team's next project, Promoting Investigators' Capacity in STEM Education Literature Synthesis (PICSELS; NSF-2422287), which will host multi-day events to guide participants deeply into their respective meta-synthesis projects, as well as provide them with curricula and pedagogy to teach meta-synthesis to others.

Intellectual Merit: Knowledge Dissemination

A major contribution of the IMS project to the field is its detailed, practical user guide, entitled, An Introduction to Qualitative Meta-Synthesis: A Method for Equity-Minded Researchers. The eight modules featured in the guide provide step-by-step guidance on conducting a meta-synthesis project and on writing synthesis manuscripts and grant proposals. Additionally, the guide includes practical examples, activities, and a glossary of terms. The team worked with professional editors and graphics designers to create a high-quality resource. The user guide (221 pages) is free to download at https://info.terc.edu/ims-an-introduction-to-qualitative-meta-synthesis.

The IMS team additionally contributed to the STEM education field a magazine article (Silva et al., 2024); a TERC STEM for All Video Showcase video (Silva et al., 2023); and a curated project website (Institute for Meta-Synthesis, 2022). The article and video provide informational overviews about IMS. The website houses basic project information as well as the project's permanent resources. To date, IMS materials have been downloaded nearly 5,000 times.

Broadening Participation: Enhancing Cultural Awareness

IMS increased the research capacity of the STEM education research communities, with particular emphasis on supporting members of historically underrepresented groups and/or students and faculty who are located at minority-serving institutions (MSIs). MSIs that served as partner institutions with IMS included the University of Massachusetts - Boston and Fort Valley State University. The advanced workshop emphasized projects grounded in equity and inclusion in STEM education. Furthermore, the IMS team consistently drew examples from STEM education equity and inclusion literature in their trainings, including the team's own completed meta-synthesis projects. As a result, participants' awareness of synthesis findings, research gaps, and the need for more underrepresented researchers studying equity and inclusion topics were enhanced. 

References

Institute for Meta-Synthesis [website]. (2022). TERC. https://www.terc.edu/metasynthesis/

Ong, M., Jaumot-Pascual, N., Torres, L. E., Silva, C. B., & Martinez-Gudapakkam, A. (2024). An introduction to qualitative meta-synthesis: A method for equity-minded researchers [video]. TERC. https://info.terc.edu/ims-an-introduction-to-qualitative-meta-synthesis

Silva, C.B., Jaumot-Pascual, N., Ong, M., & Torres-Gerald, L.E. (Spring 2024). The Institute for Meta-Synthesis: Bring meta-synthesis methods to STEM education research. Hands On! Magazine, pp. 10-13. https://www.terc.edu/hands-on-magazine-spring-2024/

Silva, C.B., Jaumot-Pascual, N., Ong, M., & Torres-Gerald, L.E. (2023, November 14). The Institute for Meta-Synthesis: Purpose, activities, and outcomes [video]. TERC STEM for All Video Showcase. https://www.terc.edu/videolibrary/videos/the-institute-for-meta-synthesis-purpose-activities-and-outcomes/
